I'm not sure how it could be a bug. It's really a binary choice: either an account can remote log in or it can't. If you want to scp to an account, then you have to be able to log in. Otherwise it would be a huge security flaw: people could put things on your computer as root without demonstrating that they know the password. Remote root login is a greater security flaw than no remote root login, but it is less a security flaw than allowing people to pu

BTW did you mean "can I do this without having to enter the password each time?" Then there is a different answer: you can use ssh-keygen to allow automatic remote log in. You still need to set a root password, and you are still using it. But the public/private key pair mean that you don't have to actually type the password.
